handDesc.handNote: Unknown Hand This hand is unknown but thought not David Livingstone's.

figure.figDesc: Map of a river and its bank with notations, including Loanda, Huia, Hangiro, people Usne, Kiziwa, Kitbara, Nyankora, Pororo, and, Kasa.

div.p:
Ngoha fine fish
Thabib = physician

My men left Zanzibar
in end of October 1870
& were at BagamoioBagamoyo
till latter part of FebyFebruary 1871 -
& at Unyanyembe -
beginning of May 1871
one left Unyanyembe

20th September 1871
5 months at UnybeUnyanyembe
to Ujiji on 10th NovrNovember

Sueli hadrasaniHadrasani
slave of Syde bin Salem
Marhobe
To-fiki = Banian slave
gone to Kutch
Ali ? says he is fine
Asmane = Garzilia = left

FebFebruary18th Dr Kirk
came over to hunt
for a week & when he
was returning called to
see my people they had
gone two days before his
arrival to hunt

Sheikh Hasheed =
an honest Arab o
Zanzibar - who trusts
to Jetta bought 22000
dollars for 28 dollars

p.hi:
November 15th Start
to go down Tanganyika
with Henry M Stanley

div.p:
2221 = passedPassed a very crowded
population = men called
us to land to be fleeced
and insulted by way of
Mohonga or mutuariMutari = they
threw stones in rage and
one apparently slung
lighted close to the canoe
We came on until after dark
and landed under a cliff
to rest & cook but a crowd
came and made enquiries
Then a few more came as if
to enquire more perfectly
toldTold us to sleep & tomorrow
friendship should be made
Put luggage on board and
set a watch on cliff - a
number of men came along
cowering behind rocks which
then aroused suspicion
and we slipped off quietly
They called after us as men
baulked of their prey - We
then went on 5 hours &
slept - then this morning
on to Magala where people
are civil but Mukamba
has war with some one
Lake Narrows to about ten
miles by Western mountains
come towards the Eastern
range that being about NNWNorth Northwest
magnetic -

Many stumps of trees killed
by water shewshow encroach-
ment of Lake on East side
a transverse range seems to
shut in the North end
but open country to the EEast & WWest
of its ends

24th toTo point Kizuka in
Mukamba's country -
a Molongwana came to
us from Mukamba
and asserted most
positively that all the
water of Tanganyika
flowed into RRiver Lusize
and thence on to Ukerewe
of Mteza = Nothing could
be more clear than his
statements

25th cameCame on about 2
hours to villages on a
high bank where Mukam-
-ba is living = the chief
came = a young good
looking man like to
Mugala and welcomed
us - Our friend of
yesterday now declared
as positively as before
that the water of Lusize
flowed into Tanganyika
and not the way he
said yesterday! I have
not the smallest doubt
but Tanganyika discharges
somewhere though we
may be unable to find it
Lusize goes to ^ or comes
from Luanda and
Karagwe = This is
hopeful = but I suspend
my judgment -

War rages between
Mukamba and War-
mashanya or Uar-
masane = a chief between
this & Lusize = ten
men were killed of
Mukamba's people a
few days ago - vast
numbers of fishermen
ply their calling night
and day as far as we
can see - Tanganyika
closes in except at one
point NNorth & by West of us
Highest point of Western
range about 7000 feet above
the sea is Sumburuza
We are to go tomorrow
to Luhinga elder of Mu-
-kamba near Lusize
chief follows us next
day

26th NovrNovember 1871 S.Sunday
Mr Stanley severe fever
gave Mukamba 9 dotis
and 9 fundos =

End of Tanganyika seen
clearly is rounded off
about 4' broad from
East to West

27th Mr S.Stanley better = start at
sunset and go WWest then to N.North
for seven hours and at
4 AM reach Lohinga
at mouth of Lusize

28th shotShot Ibis religiosa
afternoon LohingaLuhinga the
superior of Mukamba
came and shewedshowed him-
self very intelligent - He
named 18 Rivers 4 of
which enter Tanganyika
and the rest Lusize
All come into none
leave Tanganyika -
Lusize is said to rise
in Kwangeregere
in Kivo territory
between Mutumbe &
Luanda

Nyabungu is chief of
Mutumbi

Luhinga is the most
intelligent and frankest
chief we have seen here

29th goGo to see Lusize R.River
in canoe = mouth filled with
large reedy sedgy islets - three
- branches about 12 = 15 ydsyards
broad & one fathom deep = a
strong current = 2' per hour
water discoloured

30th largeLarge present of
eggs flour and a sheep
from Mukamba Mr
Stanley went round to a
Bay in the West to which
the mountains come
sheer down =

1st December 1871
Friday - Latitude last
night 3° 18' 34" SSouth
gave 15 cloths to Lohinga
which pleased him highly

Kivo = lagoon
Kuansibura chief
from it the Lusize rises
and flows under a rock
2nd = illIll from bilious attack

3d betterBetter & thankful -
men off to bring Mukamba
MukambasMukamba's wife brought a
handsome present of milk
beer & cassava = a good looking
young woman of light colour
^ full lips with two children 8 or ten years
of age - We gave them cloths -
and she asked beads = gave 2
fundos

Lunars being 2nd Ast T.Astronomical Time
and I was one day wrong

4th veryVery heavy rain
from N.North all night =
BakersBaker's Lake cannot be
near as he puts it in
his map for it is un-
known to Lohinga's
He thinks that he is
a hundred years old
about 45 really

Namataranga = birds
float high in air in
large flocks

5th goGo over to a point on
our East - Bay is about 12'
broad = mountains very
beautiful = visited chief
Mukamba at his village
5 miles North of LohingasLohinga's
wanted us to remain a
few days = but I declined
saw stwo flocks Ibis Religiosa
numbering in all 60 birds
feeding like geese
6th remainRemain at Luhinga

7th startStart and go S S W South South West to vilvillage
Lohanga pass the
RtRivulet where Speke turned
then breakfast at the
market paceplace -

8th goGo on to Mukamba
RtRivulet near boundary of
Babembe & Bavira
people shot by Malongwana
Bavira on coast the
Babembe on MtsMountains tops

We pulled six hours to a
rocky islet with two rocks
covered with trees on its West
and near - Babembe are
said to be dangerous
on account of having
been slaughtered by the
Malongwana LatLatitude 3 41' ?

9th leaveLeave NYNew York Herald islet
and go S.South to Lubumba cape
the people now are the
Basansa along coast -
men drunk & troublesome
gave a present and left
them about 4 ½1/2 afternoon
went to islet N ENorth East end
in about 3 hours -
good pulling -

Then 8 hours to Eastern
shores = 11 hours say
28 or 30 miles broad
coast along ^ 5 HHourse = to Mokungo
and rest =

10th reachReach Mokungo 9½1/2 AM
Kisessa is chief of all
islet Mozima his son
was maltreated at Ujiji &
died in consequence
this stopped the dura trade
and we were not assaulted
because not Malongwana

11th Leave Mokunga at
6 AM and coast along 6 ½1/2
hours to Sazzi

12th Mr S.Stanley ill with fever
off and after 3 hours stop
at Masambo vil.village.

13th Mr S.Stanley better = go on to
Ujiji = Mr S.Stanley recievedreceived a
letter from Consul Webb
(American) of 11th June
last and telegrams
from Aden up to 29th
April = I recievedreceived none
Dr Kirk had been
busily entertaining the
Admiral and fleet

14th Many people off to
fight Mirambo at Un-
yanyembe - their wives
promenade & wave -
green leaves for victory

15th December 1871 atAt
Ujiji - getting ready to
march East for my
goods.

Sungomazi in one
bag 750 = & in other 759

16th - engageEngage paddlers to
go to Tongwe = and a guide

17th S.Sunday 18th writing 19th
20th still writing Despatch
Packed up the large tin box
with Manyema swords
spear heads = for trans-
-mission home by Mr
Stanley = Two chrono-
meters and two watches
Anklets of Nzige and
of Manyema = Leave
with Muhamad
bin Saleh a box with
books shirts paper &c
also large & small beads
tea coffee sugar
22nd Stanley ill of fever

23d DoDitto very ill = rainy
and uncomfortable
24th S.Sunday 25th Christmas

Bag of Beads skin - 2 bags
of sungo maize ^ 746 & blue & 756 w - GardnersGardner's =
bag of beads =
soap 2 bars = 3 boxes =
= wood - 1 = Tea & Matunda
2d wooden box = paper shirts
3d iron box shoes quinine
bag coffee - sextant stand -
2 sextants = 1 long wooden empty
Left with Muhamad bin
Saleh at Ujiji Christmas
day 1871 = 2 bags of
beads already here & table-
-cloths =

26th hadHad but a sorry
Christmas yesterday

27th To send Moenyeghere
some coffee & tell his
wishes to Masudi

27th leftLeft Ujiji 9 AM
and crossed goats donkeys
and men over Luiche
about 4' of Eschinomena
and sleep at Masala
from RRiver ptpoint to BangweBangweolo
295 - 10 = 285 or 15° of WWest
Ue point from
BangweBangweolo 15° SSouth of East
Kabogo about due South
Rombola ptpoint SSESouth Southeast

Note. aboveAbove the fine yellow
clay schist of Manyema
the banks of Tanganyika
reveal 50 feet of shingle
mixed with red earth -
above this at some parts
great boulders lie - then
sixty feet fine clay schist
Then strata five 5 of gravel
under with a foot stratum
of schist between - - -
1st gravel 2 ftfeet - 2nd 4 ftfeet &
lowest about 30 ftfeet thick
the fine schist was
found in still water but
the shingle must have
been in troubled stormy
seas if not carried hither
and thither by ice and at
different epochs
sleepSleep at R.River Malagarasi

29th DecrDecember 1871 crossedCrossed over
the broad bay of the Mala-
-garasi to Kagonga &
sleep

30th passPass Viga ptpoint - red sandstone
and cross bay of R.River Luguvu
& ^ Mo Nkala vil.village and cross over
people & goats. sleep -

31st sendSend for beans as
no provisions in front of
this - Brown water of the
Lugufu bent away North
though wind is SWSouthwest & WWest

Having provisions we
went round Munkalu
ptpoint - water slightly discolour-
ed for a mile South of it
but brown water on the
North side of Bay bent NNorth

1st January 1872 May
the Almighty help me
to finish my work this
year for ChristsChrist's sake

We slept in Mosehezi
bay - I was storm stayed
in Kifwe bay which is
very beautiful still as a
mill pond & 12 or 13 hip-
-popotami near a high
bank - did not kill
for balls are not harden-
-ed - High rocky tree coverdcovered
shore - rocks bent &
twisted wonderfully
Large slices worn off
land - hill sides clad with
thick robes of living green
yet very very steep

figure.figDesc: Map of a river with name notations, including Chirewa Creek & islet, Sehumpa bay, Kabo bay, Sebarabamnyombe bay, Tburaeky shore, Kabogo's wife point, Kabogo point (the man), Mosehezi bay & River, Kibwe bay, Kibwe bay & cavern, Mongala point, Loguva River, Viga point, Kagonga, Malagarasi River, Linela River, and BangweBangweolo. Finally, the map indicates that the distance of this stretch of river is about 5 hours long.
Geographical calculations.
Geographical calculations relating to the course of Kibanga to places that include Kabago and Tongwe.

Map of a river with name notations, including Burumba or Urumba, Kibanga, Loajere River, Mogambadzi River, Boremba, Mogondozi Bay, Moherembive Bay, Bolassia River and point, and Chirewa River. The map also notes that Kaludu is South South East. Finally, the map indicates that the distance of this stretch of river is about 3 hours long.

div.ab:
say 7½1/2 hours from Mosehezi bay
to Borimba say about 20'
Mepo the Great Bay
div.p:
2nd January 1872.
a very broad belt of
large tussocks of reeds
lines the shore near
Mt.Mount Kibanga or Boumba
We had to coast along to
the South - saw a village
nearly afloat - people
having there taken refuge
from their enemies
Many hippopotami &
crocodiles in Tangan-
yika - a river 30 yards
the Kibanga flows in
strongly = encamped on
open space on knoll &
put up flags to guide the
land party to us -

3d sendSend off to buy food
Mr SStanley shot a fat zebra
meat very good = failed

4th Ujijians left last
night with canoes - gave
14 fundos of beads to
buy food inon way

4th January 1872 -
waitingWaiting for our land
party - gave headman
here at Burimba 2
dotis & a Kitamba doti
Men arrived yesterday
or 4 ½1/2 days from Lugufu

5th Mr Stanley ill of fever
copying notes into journal
all men & goats arrived
safely

6th Mr Stanley better & we
prepare to go

7th Mr Stanley shot a buffalo
at end of our first march
up East & across hills
River Luajere in front
spend night at carcass. 3

8th crossedCrossed the River 30 ydsyards
rapid now knee & waist
deep = country rich & 3
beautiful = hilly and
tree covered = reddish soil East
game abundant

9th Rainy but we went
on EEast + ENEEast Northeast through a
shut in valley - to opening
full of all kinds of game
Buffalo cows have calves
now - one wounded - Rain
came down abundantly 3½1/2

10th acrossAcross a very lovely
green country - open
forest all fresh & like an
English gentleman's
park - game plentiful -
tree covered mountains
right & left and much
Brown Haematite on the
levels - Course E.M. 4
a range about 3 miles
off on our right -

figure.figDesc: Drawing of the countryside referenced in text with "green patch" and "end of ridge camp then gap W.West" notated.

div.p:
11th offOff through flat open
forest for 3 hours East
then cook and go on East
other 3 hours - over very
rough rocky hills
country - RtRivulet Mtambu 6

12th pffOff early and pouring
rain came down as we
advanced = country undu-
lating - cross a rivulet
15 yards - going N.North and at
another of 3 ydsyards came to a
halt all wet & umcomfort-
-able - People pick up many
mushrooms & Manendinga
roots like turnips - buffaloes
near us in great numbers

13th fineFine morning - went
through undulating hilly
country clothed with up-
-land trees for 3 hours
then breakfast in an
open glade with bottom of
rocks of brown Haematite
& a hole with rain water
in it - over 1000 feet higher
than Tanganyika -
over clouded & we finished
march in pouring rain
at a rivulet thickly
clad with aquatic trees
on banks = E.SE.East Southeast 4½1/2

14th January 1872 = an-
-otherAnother fine morning but
miserably wet afternoon
Went about 4' E S EEast Southeast &
cross a strong rivulet 8 or
10 yards - then on up to a
ridge & along top of it going
about South - breakfast
on edge of plateau looking
down into a broad lovely
valley - Descended and
saw many reddish monkeys
which made a loud out-
-cry - much game but
scattered & we got none
wet miserable crossing
of another stream - then
up a valley to see a deserted
Boma or fenced village 5

15th alongAlong valley with high
MtsMountains on each hand - then up
over that range on our left
or South = at Top some
lions roared - We then
went on on high land
saw many Hartebeests
and zebras but did not
get one though a buffalo
was knocked over - crossed
a rivulet and away over
beautiful undulating
hills & vales - many trees
and Jambros fruit sleep at
a running rill S.E.Southeast 5½1/2

16th January 1872 - veryVery
cold night after heavy &
long continued rain -
camp was among brakens
Went EEast & by S.South along the
highland - Then we
saw a village down in
a deep valley into which
we descended - then up
another ridge in valley
and along to village well
cultivated - up again
700 feet at least and
down to Merera's village
hid in a mountainous
nook - about 140 huts
with doors on one side
The valleys present
Drawing of a hut referenced in text. a lovely scene
of industry - all
being eagerly engaged in
weeding & hoeing to
take advantage of the
abundant rains which
have drenched us
every afternoon SESoutheast = 5
return W NW.West Northwest

17th Remain Mrera'sMerera's ato
buy food for men and
-selvesourselves - first day W NWWest Northwest
2nd & 3d days N.W.Northwest then
when West of Magdala
due West to Borumba -
Ten days to go there

18th marchMarch but the
Chirongosi wandered &
led us round about
instead of S.SE.South Southeast came
near some tree covered
hills and a RtRivulet Monya
maze - Mtamba RtRivulet
in front = very sore
feet bad shoes 4½1/2

19th January 1872
Went about SESoutheast for 4 hours
crossed Mbamba RtRivulet and
passed through open forest
Large rock in RtRivulet and hills
thickly tree covered 2' East
and West - down a steep
descent & camp - 4½1/2

Geographical calculations. 20th DoDitto
At Mpokula Ruins -

figure.figDesc: Geographical calculations.

div.p:
came down RtRivulet Mpokwa
over rough country
sore feet - to ruins of
village of Basivira
and sleep - 3

21st Rest - 22nd - Mr SStanley
shot 2 zebras yesterday
& a she giraffe to daytoday
The meat of the Giraffe
was a thousand lbpounds weight
the two zebras about 800
23d Rest - Mr SStanley fever

figure.figDesc: Meteorological calculations.

div.p:
26th throughThrough low hills NENortheast
and among bamboos
to open forest - on in
undulating bushy DoDitto to
a RtRivulet with two rounded 4
hills East - one having
3 mushroom shaped trees

27th onOn across long
land waves & the only
bamboos East of Mpokwa
Rill to breakfast and in
going on I was attacked by
a furious swarm of bees
and badly stung on face
and head - Donkey nearly
killed by them EEast ½1/2 NNorth 6

Slept in stockade
Misonghi = Yokonongoi

28th Cross RtRivulet and then
away EEast to near a hill
cross two RrsRivers broad &
marshy - and deep with
elephants'elephant's plungings
Rain almost 2½1/2 or 3
daily but less in
amount now

Bombay Drawing of Bombay's head.
says his
greatest
desire
is to visit
Speke's
grave ere
he dies -
square head of
Bombay
top depressed
in centre =
sold off the
gold medal
given to him
by Speke &
Grant

29th ascendedAscended a ridge
the edge of a flat basin
with ledges of dark
brown sandstone the
brim of ponds in
which were deposited
great masses of brown
Haematite = disintegrated
into gravel - flat open
forest with short grass
crossed a rill of light
coloured water 3 times
reached a village &
then 1½1/2 hour Merera's
about S.E.South East 4½1/2
much arum plants

30th At Merera's the
2nd of the name = Much
rain & very heavy
food abundant --
Banyamwezi people
Yukonongo DoDitto

31st Through scraggy
bush - then open forest
with short grass - over
a broad rill and on
good path to village
= Mwaro - chief Kamir-
-ambo 4½1/2

1st February 1872
We met a caravan of
Syde bin Habib's people
yesterday who report
that Mirambo has
offered to repay all the
goods he has robbed
the Arabs of - all the ivory
powder = blood &c
but his offer was
rejected = country all
around devastated
& Arab force is at
Simba's = Shaw is
dead = very great
mortality by small
pox among Arabs and
at the coast

1st overOver flat upland
forest open & bushy
Then down a deep de-
-scent and along N.E.North East
to a large tree at Boma
deserted 4½1/2

2nd awayAway over ridges
of cultivation & elephantselephants'
footsteps = lost sight of
path = cultivators all
swept away by Ma-Basa-
=rambovira - very many
elephants feed here =
- lost trail & sent men to
seek it then came to the
camp in forest Lunched 4½1/2
at rill running into
Ngombe Nullah -
Ukamba = tsetse

3d Mr Stanley has
severe fever with great
pains in back and
legs = an emetic helped
a little but Resin of
Jalap would have
cured him quickly
Rainy all day -

4th February 1872
Mr Stanley so ill we
carried him in a cot
across flat forest &
land short grass
for three hours about
NorNorth East - found a
path = a great help =
As soon as men got
under cover continued
Rains began O. camp 3
of Malongwana = trees peeled
to make bark cloth

5th Off at 6 AM Mr SStanley a little
better but still carried
across same level forest =
pass water in pools &
one in Haematite - saw
a black Rhinoceros &
come near people 5½1/2

6th drizzlyDrizzly morning but
we went on & in two
hours got drenched with
cold NWNorthwest rain - paths
full of water = splashed
along to camp in a
wood = met a party
of native traders going
to Fipa = Mwara 2

x7th alongAlong level plains
with clumps of forest
& hollows filled at
present with water
about N-E.North East to a large
pool of Ngombe Nullah
send off two men 4
to Unyanyembe
for letters & medicine

8th removedRemoved from the
large pool of the Nullah
about an hour North to
where game abounds
saw Giraffes & zebras
inon way - Nullah cover-
ed with Lotus plants
& swarming with
crocodiles 1

9th February 1872
Remained for game
but unsuccessful
an eilandeland shot by Mr SStanley
but lost - depart at
2. PM. & reached
Manyara a kind old chief
country flat and covered
with detached masses
of forest with open 4
glades & flats

10th Leave Manyara &
pass along same fine
park like country &
but little water - Rain
sinks into the sandy soil
at once and the collection
is seldom seen = came
after a hard tramp
to a pool by a sycam-
-ore tree 28 feet nine
in circumferancecircumference &
broad fruit laden
branches
Ziwane NNENorth North East. 5½1/2

11th Rain nearly all night
scarcely a day has passed
without it & thunder since
we left Tanganyika =
across flat forest again -
Meet caravan for Ujiji -
grass 3 feet high in seed -
Reach KirChikuru a stockade
village with dura planta-
-tions around it & pools
of rain water 4½1/2

12th Rest - 13th leaveLeave
Chikuru & wade across
an open flat with much
standing water - They
plant rice on the wet
around villages = open
forest - many trees
killed for the bark
used as cloth - roofing
beds - Mr Stanley
seversevere fever 4

14th February 1872 acrossAcross same
flat open forest with
scraggy trees & grass 3
feet long in tufts
came to Boma 4½1/2
Rainy - N ENorth East Gunda

15th sameSame kind of
country = water stagnant
to camp 42 way in forest 4½1/2

16th Binda & past it
camp near Kigando
in rolling country
granite knolls

17th over country chiefly
level & water stagnant -
rounded hills seen =
cross a rain torrent
and camp in a new
Boma Mogonda 5½1/2

18th goGo through among
granite low tree covered
hills with blocks of
rock sticking out -
& much cultivation
crops swarding &
many villages - country
opens out & we come
to Tembe in midst of
many straggling villages
Unyanyembe 3¾3/4
Thanks to the Almighty

19th Rest = RecieveReceive
38 coils brass wire from
Mr Stanley = 14½1/2 bags
of beads = 12 copper
sheets = strong canvas
tent = air bed = Boat
trousers = nine loads
of calico - bath - cooking
pots - & medicine chest
Good lot of tools = tacks
screw nails = copper DoDitto
Books = medicines -
= paper = tar =
Many cartridges and
shot

20th February 1872 To my great joy
got 4 flannel shirts
from Agnes = 2 prpair of
Seadon's boots from
Waller = Mr StMr Stanley & I
measure calico &
find 733¾3/4 ydsyards wanting
2 frasilahs samsam
DoDitto and one case Brandy
DoDitto Othman pretended
sickness blamed ^ - but dead men produced
a bale of calico hidden in
Thani's goods - this
reduced the missing to
436½1/2 ydsyards

21st February 1872 Heavy rains = glad
we are in shelter
Masude an Arab
near to Ali bin Salem
at BagamoioBagamoyo =
Bushir an Arab
for whose slave
he took a bale =
Masudi took this
Chirongozi not a
slave as a pagazi -
Robbed by Bushir
5th camp from Baga-
-moio-moyo Othman
confessed that he knew
of the sale of the box of
brandy & brought
also a shawl he had
forgotten I searched him
& found Mr SStanley stores
which he had stolen too -
22 Service this
morning thanks for
safety thus far -
got a packet of letters
from an Arab -

23d Send to governor
for box which he
has kept for four
years - all eaten by
white ants - 2 fine
guns & pistol quite
destroyed = wood
work all eaten -
Brandy bottles broken
to make appear as if
by accident but
cork driven in and
maize cob cork used -
shewedshowed that thief
had drunk it & broke
bottles - Tea spoiled -
= china safe = cheese good

24th February 1872 -
Writing a Despatch to
Lord Granville agnagainst
Banian slaving and
English native settle-
ment transfer

25th numberNumber of Batusi
women came asking
present - tall and
graceful forms = well
shaped small heads
noses & mouths
they are the chief owners
of cattle here - War
with MirambuMirambo still
going on - Governor
ashamed to visit me

26th writingWriting Journal
and Despatch

27th Moenemokaia ill
of heart disease and liver abscess ^ = send
blistering fluid - Hold
a christmasChristmas feast

28th writingWriting journal
Syde bin Salem called
a China looking man
tried to be civil to us

figure.figDesc: Calculations.
Calculations.

div.p:
5th March My
friend Moenemokaia
came yesterday very
ill of abscess in liver
which burst internally
gave him calcalomel & jalap
to open bowels = is
very weak - legs swollen
but body emaciated -

6th Repairing tent
& recevereceive boat & cartridge
and tools &c &c MMoenemokaia died

7th machineMachine for filling
cartridges weighing walk
caps

10th S. Suliman
Dawa or Dowa

11th writingWriting Gave
Mr Stanley a cheque
for RsRupees 5000 on
Ritchie Stuart & Co
Bombay - This £500
is to be drawn if
Kirk has made
away with all the
rest of the £1000 if
not then it is to be
destroyed by Mr S.Stanley

12th writingWriting = 13th
finish letter to Mr Bennett
of New York Herald &
Despatch No 5 LdLord Granville

14th Mr Stanley
leaves - I commit to his care my journal
sealed with 5 seals
American gold coin -
anna & ½1/2 & cake of
paint with royal
arms - Positively
not to be opened

15th March 186872
writingWriting to send after
Mr Stanley by two
of his men who wait
here for the purpose -
copied line of route
obsnsobservations from Kabure
to Cazembe is the 2nd
visit and on to Lake
Bangweolo - then the
- experiment of weight
on watch key at
Nyangwe & Lusize

16 sentSent the men after
Mr Stanley & two of
mine to bring his last
words if any -
17th S.Sunday service =

19th Birthday = My
Jesus, my King, my
life, my all = I again
dedicate my whole self
to thee = accept me and
grant O Gracious Father
that ere this year is
gone I may finish
my task = In Jesus
name I ask it -
Amen, so let it be -
David Livingstone

20th Heavy rain in night
copying Astro.Astronomical obsnsobservations

21th Read BakersBaker's
book - It is artistic &
clever = Bragging is his
forte - He does good
service in exposing
the Nile slave trade
I hope he may be success-
-ful - suppressing it

22nd March 1872
Rains almost every
night shewshow Masika has
been going on here

23d copyingCopying AstroAstronomical -
ObsnsObservations for Sir T.Thomas Maclear

24th S.Sunday service - 25th
Susi brought a letter
back from Mr Stanley
5 days off - had a little
fever but I hope he
will go on safely

26th Rain of Masika
chiefly by night Masika of 1871 began
23d March & ended 30
April -

27th Reading = very
heavy rains

28th Moenyembegu
asked to loan of a
doti = He is starving
& so is the war party
at Mfutu = chaining
their slaves to keep
them from running
away to get food any-
where

31st Park's Travels
they look so truthful
none of Baker's brag.

1st April 1872
Read Young's search
Expedition book
thankful for many
kind words about
me = He writes like
a gentleman

2nd April 1872
send for lost book to
Gunda = making
sounding line out of
lint left by Mr Stanley

4th We hear that DugumbesDugumbe's
men have come to
Ujiji with 50 tusks
He went down Lualaba
with three canoes a
long way & bought much
- ivory = were not
molested by Monan=
-gungo in coming as we
were -
Milk begins on 4th = 24th

Men came back stopped
by a flood in the
way back for my book
copying observations
for Sir T.Thomas MaclearsSir T.Thomas Maclear's

6th sendSend off to buy Holons
Sorghum to make bread
This is nearer to wheat
than maize = New ☾

7th S.Sunday service = The Banza-
-mivezi told the Arabs that
they did not want them
to go to fight because
when one Arab was killed
all the rest ran away
and the whowhole army got
frightened in consequence
Give us your slaves only
& we will fight = Magohe
man gave charms and
yesterday they pressed
Mirambo sorely = His
brother sent 4 tusks
as a peace offering -
and it is thought that
the end is near - His
mother was plundered
& lost all her cattle

8th anAn Arab called
Seyed bin Muhamad
Magibbe called he
proposes to go West
to beyond Katanga
(Urenge) - Finish
coppyingcopying obsnsobservations at
Pambellier for S T.Sir Thomas Maclear

9th April 1872
About 150 Waganga of
Mteza carried a present to
Seyed Burghash of ivory
& a young elephant
He spent all the ivory in
buying return presents
of gun powder guns
soap = brandy gin &c
and they have it in
this tembe = this morning
They have taken all out
to see if it is not spoiled
hundreds of packages

10th sixteenSixteen of MirambosMirambo's
wives escaped & were
captured = they report
that he has now only one
barrel of powder & one
box of balls = Kasera his
brother of chief man fled

11th S.Sunday - 12th oneOne of the
Baganda of Mteza
told me yesterday that
Dubale is the name
for Deity in his tongue

13th sendSend for book
again = no rain having
fallen since 2nd they will
be able to cross country

15th Thursday = hungHung up
the sounding line on
poles 1 fathom apart &
tarred it = 373 fathoms
of five strands

Visit Sultan Ali at
Tabora = Make a present
Abed bin Salem = Le-
-hedere is my friend
down Lualaba =

Heard that Dugumbe's
large party over at
Lomame was caught
on two sides right &
left with an open
front and seventy
of them slain the
good Lord kept me
from falling there -
Had I gone I could not
have escaped - It
was a complete rout.
swift vengeance it
looks for the massacre
at Nyangwe I offer hearty
thanks for double
preservation

17th Reading = found
the lost book -
18th S.Sunday service

19th A Roll of letters
and newspapers
apparently came
Today for Mr Stanley
Messenger says that
he passed Mr S.Stanley - on
the road & he said
take that to the Dr
this is erroneous
Prince of Wales is
reported to be dying
of Typhoid Fever
He refused his own
sister Louise entrance
to a state Ball! Louise
hastened to his bedside

20th April 1872
Opened the tin tube in
which were found are
letterletters for Mr Stanley
and nine New York
Heralds of DecrDecember 1 - 9
1871 and a cake of
tobacco =

21st Tarred the tent
presented by Mr Stanley

p.seg:
a few daysdays' rain
and now it ceases = We
had a good spell of heavy
night rains before and
after 22nd March - then
a cessation = Now there
is a second cessation

div.p:
Kimera first Mohuma
came from Unyoro
Bialo = land of Raganda
Kira - name of Lake Okan

23d visitVisit Kwikuru
to Muhamad bin Syde
5th Safura moon last of Masika now
6th Rabia next month
the Masika being
finished all the traders
will leave Zanzibar
for Interior

p.seg:
Heavy rain shewsshows
Masika not finished yet

div.p:
25th S.Sunday 26th touch
of fever from exposure
27th better & thankful

Zahor died of small
pox here after collecting
much ivory at Fipa
and Urungu = all
taken up by Lewale

29th Writing letter to Bn
Sheikh But called -

30th 2200 + 3300 = 5500
Samaritan = 5506 - years
Masoretic chchapter 4 = 5861
Septuagint chchapter 4 6447

1st May 1872 Buy a
cow from Baganda = for
11 dotis = & 2d for calf -
about £ 1-5 = at Zanzibar

Head man Sinjeri
said that he was going to
pray = He has been taught
by the Arabs & is the first
proselyte in these lands =
Speke and Baker taught
them to distil brandy by
a gun barrels and Tozer
dawdles at Zanzibar

Finished a letter for
New York Herald of
20 pages = 5400 words
or 2 columns close print
Trying enlist American
Zeal to stop East Coast
slave trade = I pray for a
blessing on it from the
all Gracious = 2 cows &
calves more give plenty
of milk 24 dotis = £2.10

2nd May S.Sunday service - a
shower about 4 AM.
Gave a Motusi a doti to
milk & herd the cows for
2 months

3d boughtBought a fourth
cow from Singere a
Muganda from Mtesa
10 dotis & 3 for calf - a
4th doti as a present
Rains very heavy in
evening & early morning

4th May 1872.
Lewale came from
Mfutu = & called here
Prepared tracing paper
to draw a map for
Sir Thomas Maclear

5th 6th Lewale invites
to a feast = Sultan bin
Ali's son died yester-
day = one nightsnight's illness

7th New ☾ last night
Went & break fasted
with Lewale = says
that the Mirambo man
is virtually against
himself as a Syed
Majid man = They wish
to have him removed &
this would be a benefit

8th Masika ceased
on 5th being true new ☾
that is from 23d April to
5th May = 12 days but
rains fell plentifully
before that

Nkasiwa = chief of the
Banyamwezi at
Kwikuru = expects to be
attacked today by one
Maganga = also a Mo-
-nyamwezi
9th S.Sunday service

10th News came that
Ghamees Wodin Lagh
my friend of Chitinbwa
is killed at a village of
Makoa whither he &
others went to fight &
he recievedreceived a ball through
the bowels from the
left side = other Arabs
have fallen too

Report contradicted
afterwards

11th May 1872
Found a serpent at the
door this morning
killed by a cat

p.seg:
veryVery cold winds
from the East shewshow
the rains to be quite over

div.p:
13th Njala's people
return = were robbed by
Lugaruga at Ngala

14th copyingCopying sketch map
News from Ujiji say
many of Muhamad
Bogharib's slaves have
died of small pox and
one Athman killed by Waha

15th gaveGave a bullseye
glass to Singere for
Mteza = He pressed a
cow & calf on me in vain

Lewale off to Mfutu
not to fight but to send the
Bagoye to the war

16th S.Sunday Lewale sends
off letters to Sultan today
I have no news to send
but am waiting wearily

17th ailingAiling 18th ailingAiling
in bowels = 19th betterBetter =
A man of Dugumbe
came from Ujiji
today = contradicts
previous reports
of slaughter = except
of the Bakuss = some
200 of them at Lomame

20th veryVery cold winds
cattle of the Batusi cap-
-tured by the Arabs to
prevent them going off
with the Baganda - My
four among them -
sent over for them -
and they were returned
this morning
35 of MuhamadsMuhamad's
slaves died of small pox

21st May 1872
Genuine Africans
have flattened nose
bridges = The higher
grades of the tribes have
like ManyuemaManyema high nose
bridges = this last the
Arabs consider real beauty
The possession of
positiveness must be
comfortable for a time
BakersBaker's was admirable
Cooley's insane =

p.seg:
a slight shower I
suppose the last laid dust
several similar showers
through the day

div.p: 23d S.Sunday service
24th 25th 26th 7 A.M.

Meteorological calculations that continue from previous page.

div.p:
28th May 1872
Smokes or haze begins =
and birds stimulated by the
cold build briskly
Halima contended with
Ntaoeka and on my failing
to reconcile them Halima
ran away.

29th Went over to Sultan
bin Ali at Labora & sent
a note to Lewale after
Halima = She came back of
her own accord - would not
come in till I went outside
and told her to enter and
not to quarrel with any-
one

30th S. s.Sunday service 31st oneOne of MiramboMirambo's
people routed out and fled

1st June 1872 -
3 PM detached clouds
Meteorological calculations.
visited by Jemadar
Ghamees from Katanga
with information
which see in II copy

2nd Lemon & Pomegranates
blossoming = Birds building

3d Chuma married
by Ntaoeka =

Meteorological calculations.

div.p: TipoTipo's father called

figure.head:
BarBarometer of
Unyanyembe
figure.figDesc: Meteorological calculations.

div.p:
6th 7th June 1872
Prepare sungo mazi in
a box of 4 frasilahs = 140 lbspounds
Sultan bin Ali approves
the Fipa road = the other
is in a state of war

8th Visited Lewale =
Heard of Baker going to
Unyoro water albeit Lake
thinks most of Merere's
read & will give a guide

9th 10th 11th Min. 60°
12th Min 59° Lewale called -

13th S.Sunday Min. 55°
Singara one of Mr
Stanley's men returned
from BagamoioBagamoyo &
reports my caravan as
at Ugoga - I am most
unfeignedly thankful
Stanley and Webb have
acted nobly

14th Min. 54° 6 AM =
Meteorological calculations.

15th 16th Boiling Point
near 9 AM = sky clear
air Meteorological calculations.

figure.figDesc: Meteorological calculations.
Meteorological calculations.

div.p:
First set this morning
as above in open pot
gallon & ½1/2 of water = 69° air
Meteorological calculations.

17th June 1872
SSydeultan bin Ali called & doubts
Singaro but says let us wait
to see the men arrive

18th Lewale departs
for the war to finish
Mirambo = the powder
will be pretty well
spent ere he gets there
a perpetual fusilade
seems by way of getting
their spirits up =

19th 20th S.Sunday 21st 22nd
23d Mirambo reported to
Nkasiwa as having sent
100 tusks & 100 slaves to
the coast to buy gunpowder

24th 25th boughtBought 2 oxen
as provisions for the way

26th 27th S.Sunday Went over to
Kwikuru and engaged Mu-
-hamad bin Seyde to speak
to Nkasiwa for pagazi
He wishes to go himself

28th Dugumbe's
men who went off to
Ujiji to bring ivory
returned today having
been attached by Robbers
of Mirambo - the pagazi
threw down all their
loads and ran - none were
killed but they lost all

29th RecievedReceived from Sheikh
bin Nasib a packet
containing 1 Gazette 1
overland Mail = 4 Pinches
30th slaughterSlaughter an ox

1st July makeMake a packet
for sending by one
Suleiman
by Sebh Undu
Sheikh ^ Hamua Undu his
master - Went over to
Kwikuru to address
packet in Arabic

2d July 1872 Send
ofoff a packet to coast
visit Mfutu Kwikuru
RecieveReceive OswellsOswell's note of April

3d Sultan bin Ali called
invited to visit him
4th S.Sunday 5th Weary Weary!

figure.figDesc: Meteorological calculations.
Meteorological calculations.

div.p:
8th Meteorological calculations.
All the foregoing observations
were taken from thermosthermometers
hung four feet from the
ground on the cool side
(South) of the house &
beneath an earthen roof
complete protection from
wind and radiation

Soon known by the
shadows being nearly
perpendicular - the
following protected
from wind by a reed fence
but exposed to sun's rays
slanting a little to shewshow
the heat endured at
midday by a traveller
here ends II four feet from ground
Meteorological calculations.
agreeable marching now
Meteorological calculations.

figure.figDesc: Meteorological calculations.
Meteorological calculations.

div.p:
11th July 1872 - S.Sunday
The final battle to come off
today if at all = Mirambo
12th Sheikh But stealing

figure.figDesc: Meteorological calculations.

div.p: 14th Watuta slain 200 - ?

15th 16th Visited Sultan
bin Ali = It is reported that
the headman of a stockade
near to Mirambo's set
pointed sticks in concealed
holes like Bruce with his
"craw toes" at Bannockburn
and disabled the assailants
these may be the 20 wounded
the warriors have now sent
for a cannon they have
here to battesbattle him outside
the traps which Mirambo
too has set too probably -
AM 17th Meteorological calculations.

Lewale sends off the Baganda
in a great hurry after detain-
ing them for a yearsix months or more
"till the war ended" - gets pagazi of
Banyamwezi for them - this haste
though war is not ended is pro-
-bably because Lewale has heard
of a missionary through me!

a slave killed by people
of Mirambo out prowling

Cannon going is of the
year 1679 went to China
with 1872 commander in
chief 193 Portuguese

19th visitedVisited Salem bin
Seff and was very hospitably
entertained = was disappointed
that I could not eat largely
they live very comfortably -
grow ^ wheat and flour & fruits grace
their board - says that goats-
flesh at Zanzibar is better
than beef but here beef is
better than goats flesh -
a stout jolly man -

20th July 1872
Nkasiwa returned - was
unfinished but Mirambo
fires now from inside the
stockade alone - Lewale
comes tomorrow too

21th 22nd Bought two milk
cows from a Motusi which
with their calves were 17 dotis
or 34 fathoms -

3 PM cloudy Meteorological calculation.
The Baganda
are packing up
to leave for home = they take
a good deal of brandy &
gin for Mteza from the
Moslems TempTemperature Noon 96°

23d Baganda departure
countermanded for fear
of Mirambo capturing
their gunpowder 150 barrels

24th Bagohe retire from the
war - this month unlucky
visited Lewale & Nkasiwa
put blister on latter for
paralytic arm = to please
him - Lewale says that
a general flight from the
war has taken place
excuse hunger -

figure.figDesc: Meteorological calculations.

div.p:
25th S.Sunday 26th blisterBlister did
good to Nkasiwa = went
to put on another on nape
of neck -

p.seg:
At dawn a loud
rumbling in the East as
if of thunder - possibly
a slight earthquake = No
thunder clouds visible

div.p:
Sheikh bin Aasib
came last night & called
Baganda & Arab agents
beaten back with loss
and one killed by the
scouts of Mirambo

29th 30th News of safari
coming at Ugogo = 12 days off

31st solderedSoldered tin box
and renewed powder in
the cartridges for big gun

1st August 1872 S.Sunday
visited Nkasiwa =
Baganda sent to see who
stopped the way - were de-
-tained in Usui by a
false report that the
war was finished here
they are to be sent back
to bring on reinforcements
about a thousand being
at Usui or Busubi
about 30 arrived today
2nd New ☾ this evening

3d Visited Salem bin
Seff ill of fever = hospitable
then off to Sultan bin Ali
& home = He effected the
flight of all the Baganda
pagazi by giving ten strings
of beads to a Motusi to go
& by night spread a panic
among them = all bolted =

4th - 5th Visit Nkasiwa
6th Beads for 5 days = 7th Visit
Sheikh bin Nasib =

8th S.Sunday 9th 3 men arrived
from Zanzibar = thanks
10th Beads for 6 days

11th Safari arrived
left BagamoioBagamoyo 29th May
2 + 30 + 31 + 11w = 74 days

12th serveServe Dura out
visit Sultan bin Ali

13th Dura & cloths 5
each = 23d 24th =

14th Dura = gave 4
NassikNassickers 2 dotis each
Mr S.Stanley left 14th March .....
Men arrived 11th Aug.August - 5 months

div.p:
A fellow claimed
$10 for H. Ashina and
Amoda foolishly gave
2 dotis = son of Moene-
mokaia called Moene-
dongo

16th 5 ÷x 14 = 70 Beads
Wooden cartridge box 1
Powder & cartridges

Tin boxes each with
50 packets & 2 powder
7
3500 cartridges
Fifteen shooter cartscartridges are
in a tin box with flints
680 600 rifle cartridges
empty - 450 RevolRevolver DoDitto

Lesasse has = sugar candles
Leruze has 15 Shshootershotgun cartcartridges & flints

Sundries Calculation. sextant 2
3

17th preparingPreparing things
to remain with S. bin AliSultan bin Ali

18th Fundo to be
avoided as extortionate
Went to bid adieu
to Sultan bin Ali and
left goods with him
for the return journey
and many cartridges
full & empty - nails
for boat - 2 iron pillars

19th August 1872
waiting for pagazi = Sultan
bin Ali called = is going
off to Ufutu

20th Jacob Wainwright
Rughsa
given John DoDitto =
wish to return to coast
Ulede made them cattle drivers

52 ) 26
Weighed all the loads again
and gave an equal load
of lbspounds 50 to each and
½1/2 loads to 2 Nassickers
the other two take ordinary
loads =

Mabruki L.Little is left at
Taborah with Sultan
bin Ali = has long been
sick and is unable to
go with us - very lazy too

21st gave people an ox
and a discarded wife
a cloth to avoid exposure
by her husband stripping
her = She is a somebodyssomebody's child

22nd S.Sunday all ready but 10
pagazi lacking

Start 23d cannotCannot get pagazi
most are sent off to the war

24th 25th startedStarted and
went one hour to vilvillage of
Maganga ^ or yuba by a granite ridge
the weather clear & a fine
breeze from East refreshes
It is of importance to
give short marches at first 1¼1/4

26th Two NassikcrsNassickers lost a
cow out of ten head of
cattle! March to Boma
of Mogonda = five men
sent back after the cow
cow not found = was 2 S.South
our best milker

27th August 1872
For Mbwanga vilvillage Ebalwa
& Kasekera of Mamba
cross Torrent now dry &
through forest to vilvillage Ebul-
-wa then pass on to vilvillage
Kasekera to sleep 3½1/2 SSouth by WWest

28th Reach Mayole vilvillage
in 2 hours & rest SSouth & by WWest
Water scarce in front
through flat forest to a
marshy looking piece of
water where we camp 1½1/2
altogether SSouth & by W.West 3½1/2

29th onOn through level
forest without water
at present = trees present
a dry wintry aspect
grass dry but some
flowers shoot out &
fresh grass where burned

Boys at Gunda have
made clever imitation
guns with springs
of a ship off Drawing of a rifle.the reed
of which each is formed
the hammer is mounted
on a flat square
bit of hard wood
& on moving the
hammer it clicks
like a real gun SSouth & by W.West 4½1/2

figure.figDesc: Drawing of unknown objects, perhaps two crosses.

div.p:
30th The two
Nassickers lost
all the cows yesterday
from sheer laziness
they were found a
long way off & one calf
missing - Suzi
gave them ten cuts
each with a switch
engaging pagazi & Rest

31st August 1872 passPass
Kisari's vilvillage 1¼1/4 distant
Penta or Phinta to
sleep South & by WWest 3
perfectly flat Forest

The Buganda boy Kassa
was followed to Gunda
and I delivered him to
his country men = He escaped
from Mayole vil.village this
morning & came at 3
PM his clothes in rags
by running through its
forests = 11 hours running
say 22 - and is determined
not to leave us

1st SeptrSeptember 1872 - The same
sort of level forest to the
S.South & by W.West = KwiChikulu 4 hhours - 25 mminutes
Manyara called & is
going with us Tomorrow
lasigeañgeLasigeañge presented
a leg of Kongolo
or Taghetsi having
a bunch of white hair
beneath the orbital
sinus = Gave each
man ten daysdays' rations

2nd Two pagazi escaped
taking away 24 dotis
belonging to the men
sent after them & remain

4th flatFlat country but sloping
Southwards = very dry -
course SSouth & by W.West 4¼1/4 at
Ziwane in Lakelet = Big tree

5th Off before sunrise &
reach Manyarar in 5¾3/4
people tired = Rest, SSWSouth Southwest

6th Rest the caravan = as
we must make forced marches
on account of the Tsetse

7th obligedObliged to remain
on account of fever
in several people

8th SeptrSeptember 1872 = On to
Ngombe Nullah = SWSouthwest 4
very hot & people ill - Tsetse

11th marchMarch ½1/2 & Telekeza but
remain = WWest - this is 8½1/2 in other book

12th overOver flat forest to water in
brown Haematite WWest 4

1st August SeptrSeptember 1872
A flock of small swallows
now appears = seem
tailless & white bellies √

5th sawSaw one swift = √
a very large puff adder lay
near the path gorged with
some small animal = I hit
it fair on the head & one blow
was enough = men said it was
a good sign for the journey

Tobe left with Sultan
bin Ali Merikano 5 ydsyards
Fine Kamike 4
in one bale ==

Kanike = 4 Jorhas

The young whydah birds
crouch at
night for heat - they look
like a wooly ball on a branch
By day they engage in
pairing & coaxing each
other by lifting a feather
& popping from side to side
of the mate coaxingly - they
come to the same twig every
night - Like children - they
try to lift heavy weights of
feathers above √ their strength

13th July 1872 sawSaw the
first kites today - (3) one
had spots of white
feathers on body ^ below as if
it were a young one - -
probably come from North √

21st Another nest of
Wagtails flown = eat bread
crumbs - Whydahs busy
pairing = 6 AugAugust = Wagtails
begin to discard√ the young
which feed themselves

The young = 19th June 1872
WhydawsWhydahs though full
fledged still gladly take a
feed from their dam -
putting down the breast to the
ground & cocking up the bill
and chirrupping in the
most engaging manner
and winning way they know
Dam gives a little still but
administers a friendly
shoree off too - they all
pick up feathers or grass
and hop from side to side
of mates as if saying come
let us play at making
little houses = Wagtail has
shaken her young quite off
and has a new nest -
warbles prettyily very much
like a canary - is extremely
active in catching flies
but eats crumbs of bread
and milk too - sun √
birds visit the pomegran-
ate flowers and eat insects
there in too as well as nectar

near Kasangangaze saw
boys shooting locusts
that settled on the
ground with little bows
and arrows √

The first smile of an
infant with its tooth-
-less gums is one of the
pleasantest sights in
nature = Innocence
claiming kinship and
asking to be looed in
its helplessness √

Cock WhydawWhydah bird died in
the night - brood came &
chirrupped to it for food -
tried to awake it as if not
knowing death -

Wagtail dam refused its
young a caterpillar till it
had killed it - ran away
√ from it but then gave it when
ready to be swallowed

Two WhydawWhydah birds
with black throats and
white breasts & brown on
rest of body had their nests
destroyed several times by
boys = they put back their
eggs as they have the power
to do & now build again

25th May 1872 - anotherAnother
pair of red breasted cock had
10 chickens & now rebuild
afresh - see case of Trout
in other book May 25th
Red cock bird feeds all the √
brood - each puts his head
on one side as he inserts it
in his bill = chirruping
briskly & bothering him -

The young ones lift up a
feather as a doll & invite
suspect others to do the same in
play as children make
miniature houses -
one cock & hen paired he
skips from side to side with
a feather in his bill and
she is pleased = nature
is full of enjoyment

the crop without the bow-
ing & bending of the pigeons
they chirrup briskly for food
the dam gives most while
the red breasted cock gives
to one or two & then knocks
the rest away √ in loco

region= very polite

well shaped heads

colour brown - very
pleasant to speak to
well shaped bodies
with small hands &
feet - the last with high
insteps and springy
altogether = Plants &
grass are collected
every day and a fire
with much smoke
made to fumigate
the cattle = & keep off
flies - the cattle like it

div.p: Further from Dr. Livingstone.

London, Aug.August 29. Dr. Kirk of Zanzibar writes that
Dr. Livingstone is still in the country west of the
Tanganayika and the Arabs there count him as a resi-
dent. In that region no feeling is manifested toward
him. He is moving slowly but safely, and will leave no
doubts in the geographical problem whether Lake Tan-
ganayika is the real head of the Nile, or whether it
empties by the Congo.
